description: From Middle English bateren, from Old French batre (“to beat”).

verbs.description: batter (third-person singular simple present batters, present participle battering, simple past and past participle battered)

entries.meaning: To hit or strike violently and repeatedly.
examples: The firemen battered down the door.

entries.meaning: (cooking) To coat with batter (the food ingredient).
examples: I prefer it when they batter the cod with breadcrumbs.

entries.meaning: (UK, slang, usually in the passive) To intoxicate.
examples: I was battered last night on our pub crawl.

entries.meaning: (metalworking) To flatten (metal) by hammering, so as to compress it inwardly and spread it outwardly.

description: From Middle English bature, from Old French bateure (“the action of beating”), from batre (“to beat”).

entries.meaning: (cooking, countable, uncountable) A beaten mixture of flour and liquid (usually egg and milk), used for baking (e.g. pancakes, cake, or Yorkshire pudding) or to coat food (e.g. fish) prior to frying.
examples: To the dismay of his mother, the boy put his finger into the cake batter.

entries.meaning: (countable, slang) A binge; a heavy drinking session.
examples: When he went on a batter, he became very violent.

entries.meaning: A paste of clay or loam.
(countable, printing) A bruise on the face of a plate or of type in the form.
examples: In repairing batters at the edges of the plate, when the bevel has been torn away by the catches, &c., it is necessary to solder a piece of metal along the side.

entries.meaning: An incline on the outer face of a built wall.

verbs.description: batter (third-person singular simple present batters, present participle battering, simple past and past participle battered)

entries.meaning: (baseball) The player attempting to hit the ball with a bat.
examples: The first batter hit the ball into the corner for a double.

entries.meaning: (cricket) A player of the batting side now on the field.
(cricket) The player now receiving strike; the striker.
(cricket) Any player selected for his or her team principally to bat, as opposed to a bowler.
examples: It's hard to put this on his shoulders while the guy is so young, but I firmly believe Kane could go down as New Zealand's greatest ever batter.
